awd_titl_txt: Magnetic Field Mapping of Vortex Hotspots and Identifying the Sources of Losses in Superconducting Accelerating Cavities
awd_abstract_narration:
Research in a number of areas of physics relies on the use of accelerators to generate beams of particles moving at high energy that are used in a broad spectrum of activities, from fundamental research to medical treatments to materials processing.  Most accelerator designs rely on moving the particles through a series of magnetic resonant cavities, similar to a microwave oven, to supply energy to the beam.   The very high energies that can be reached through accelerators today has been enabled by the use of superconducting magnets to supply the energy to the cavity.  But with any cavity, the behavior of the beam is strongly influenced by the structure of the magnetic field within the cavity.  This work aims at improving the performance and efficiency of superconducting resonator cavities used in modern particle accelerators by addressing the impact of irregularities in the magnetic field within the cavity. A novel experimental apparatus will be developed along with new theoretical models to carry out this study. This research will provide an opportunity to train one undergraduate and two graduate students in the field of particle accelerators and solid-state physics and will provide new methods to reduce the cost of operation of particle accelerators used in basic and applied sciences. 

The project will investigate the mechanisms of trapping and dissipation of vortices in superconducting radio-frequency (RF) niobium cavities under different conditions, such as cool-down rates, surface treatments and residual magnetic field. A novel combined temperature and magnetic scanning system will be developed to detect and quantify the amount of trapped flux and its impact on cavity RF losses. The experimental work will be integrated with numerical reconstructions of the vortex distribution and theoretical investigations of trapping of vortex bundles during the cool-down of the cavity through the critical temperature, and the contribution of vortices to the surface resistance at high RF magnetic field amplitudes.

por.por_cntn:
Superconducting radio-frequency (SRF) cavities are one of the building blocks of modern particle accelerators for scientific research. A beam of charged particles is accelerated up to high energy by the electric field inside SRF cavities and it is used as a “probe” in many sciences, ranging from biology and material science to nuclear and particle physics.

The radio-frequency losses in SRF cavities are much smaller than in normal-conducting ones thanks to the superconducting property of the material that cavities are built out of, when cooled to liquid-helium temperatures. As a result of superconductivity, SRF cavities allows for an efficient conversion of the RF power from an RF source into beam power. One of the aims of R&D in SRF science and technology is to keep increasing the efficiency of SRF cavities in order to reduce the size and cost of the complex cryogenic plants which are needed to cool the many SRF cavities inside a particle accelerator.

Any ambient magnetic field in the vicinity of a cavity can be trapped in the cavity wall as the cavity is cooled below the superconducting transition temperature. The magnetic field trapped inside the superconductor is quantized and the interaction of each flux quantum with the RF field in the cavity leads to additional RF losses.

Two high-resolution diagnostic systems have been designed, built and commissioned to find and quantify the amount of magnetic flux that is trapped in SRF cavities. One system is a rotating cryogenic magnetic field mapping system for 1.3 GHz cavities. The other is a fixed combined cryogenic temperature and magnetic field mapping system for 3 GHz cavities.

Cryogenic Hall probes and anisotropic magnetoresistance sensors were characterized as the best type of magnetic field sensors for this application.

The novel high-resolution tools showed that a higher fraction of the ambient field was trapped in the cavity and was distributed more uniformly as a result of a cool-down with more uniform temperature distribution on the cavity surface, compared to a cool-down with larger temperature gradients. It was also shown that trapped flux increases at the quench location as a result of a quench.

Numerical simulations were carried out to determine the surface resistance of a trapped flux line (also known as a vortex) as a function of the strength of the rf field and the frequency. Different pinning configurations were studied. The results showed that the average surface resistance increases linearly with increasing rf field in the low frequency regime and that it becomes non-monotonic at high field amplitudes, as a result of the dependence of the vortex viscosity on the speed of the vortex.

The project has provided the opportunities for two Physics graduate students to be trained in the highly multidisciplinary field of SRF science and technology. The experimental and theoretical work performed during the project have resulted in high-resolution tools for the scientific community to study losses due to trapped magnetic flux in large-scale, 3D superconductors as well as a detailed description of the loss mechanisms. The work completed in this project will impact future research aiming at reducing the effect of ambient magnetic fields on SRF cavities, therefore reducing further their cryogenic RF losses.
